Issues.Title: Mark eager `NgModuleFactory` construction as not side effectful
Issues.Body:
Roll forward of #38147.

This allows Closure compiler to tree shake unused constructor calls to `NgModuleFactory`, which is otherwise considered
side-effectful. The Angular compiler generates factory objects which are exported but typically not used, as they are
only needed for compatibility with View Engine. This results in top-level constructor calls, such as:

```typescript
export const FooNgFactory = new NgModuleFactory(Foo);
```

`NgModuleFactory` has a side-effecting constructor, so this statement cannot be tree shaken, even if `FooNgFactory` is
never imported. The `NgModuleFactory` continues to reference its associated `NgModule` and prevents the module and all
its unused dependencies from being tree shaken, making Closure builds significantly larger than necessary.

The fix here is to wrap `NgModuleFactory` constructor with `noSideEffects(() => /* ... */)`, which tricks the Closure
compiler into assuming that the invoked function has no side effects. This allows it to tree-shake unused
`NgModuleFactory()` constructors when they aren't imported. Since the factory can be removed, the module can also be
removed (if nothing else references it), thus tree shaking unused dependencies as expected.

The one notable edge case is for lazy loaded modules. Internally, lazy loading is done as a side effect when the lazy
script is evaluated. For Angular, this side effect is registering the `NgModule`. In Ivy this is done by the
`NgModuleFactory` constructor, so lazy loaded modules **cannot** have their top-level `NgModuleFactory` constructor
call tree shaken. We handle this case by looking for the `id` field on `@NgModule` annotations. All lazy loaded modules
include an `id`. When this `id` is found, the `NgModuleFactory` is generated **without** with `noSideEffects()` call,
so Closure will not tree shake it and the module will lazy-load correctly.

Closure does not tree shake unused `NgModule`s from the bundle.

Issue Number: http://b/161548609

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): update unparsable character reference entity error messages
Issues.Body:
Within an angular template, when a character entity is unable to be parsed, previously a generic unexpected character error was thrown. This does not properly express the issue that was discovered as the issue is actually caused by the discovered character making the whole of the entity unparsable. The compiler will now instead inform via the error message what string was attempted to be parsed and what it was attempted to be parsed as. Example, for this template: ```html

ģp

``` Before this change: `Unexpected character "p"` After this change: `Unable to parse entity "ģp" - hexadecimal character reference entities must end with ";"` Fixes #26067
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(compiler): update unparsable character reference entity error messages" (#38319)

Issues.Title: Can't user translation file for en-US: "An i18n locale ('en-US') cannot both be a source locale and provide a translation"
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report I can't use a translation file for en-US: ```json i18n": { "locales": { "en-US": { "baseHref": "delete/us/en_us", "translation": "messages.en-us.xlf" } } } ``` ### Description - Our app is translated into 40+ languages - We want our translation department to be responsible for all strings - We want to ignore the strings our developers have written in the HTML files - Therefore we need one build per messages.xlf file and no build for the "sourceLocale" - At the moment we are forced to manually copy the strings from the messages.en-us.xlf file back into our HTML every time our translation department makes a change to en-US Possible solutions: - Allow `"translation"` as a property of `"sourceLocale"` ```json "sourceLocale": { "code": "en-US", "translation": "messages.en-us.xlf" } ``` - Add option to prevent the build of the source locale ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/MartinJaskulla/angular-issue-38316 ## üî• Exception or Error 

An unhandled exception occurred: An i18n locale ('en-US') cannot both be a source locale and provide a translation.
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.7
Node: 12.13.1
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 9.0.7
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

typescript                        3.7.5
webpack                           4.41.2
**Anything else relevant?** I know that there are several workarounds. For example we could provide a non-existent source locale `"sourceLocale": "aa-aa"` and delete the build afterwards. However our app is very big and we want to save the build time. Furthermore our actual setup is more complex than the example provided above. For example the translations for the same locale e.g. my-app.com/de/en-US and my-app.com/us/en-US can be different. It would be useful for angular.json to provide some sort of nesting of the locales.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Can't user translation file for en-US: "An i18n locale ('en-US') cannot both be a source locale and provide a translation"" (#38316)

Issues.Title: The @ViewChildren decorator does not select providers defined through string tokens
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report
### Affected Package
The issue is caused by package `@angular/core`.

### Is this a regression?
Yes. This bug was not present before version 9 when Ivy was enabled by default. With ViewEngine, this bug is not present.

### Description
Although not explicitly stated in the [documentation for the `@ViewChildren` decorator](https://angular.io/api/core/ViewChildren), this decorator previously selected providers that were defined through string tokens with ViewEngine. With Ivy enabled, these providers are no longer selected. 

In the [documentation for its counterpart, the `@ViewChild` decorator](https://angular.io/api/core/ViewChild), one of the accepted selectors is stated as:

> Any provider defined through a string token (e.g. @ViewChild('someToken') someTokenVal: any)

This is broken for `@ViewChild` as well. I'm working from the expectation that the acceptable selector types for `@ViewChild` should be the same for `@ViewChildren`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/view-children-string-token-provider-selector

## üî• Exception or Error
No error, `@ViewChildren` just returns undefined values.

## üåç  Your Environment

```
Angular CLI: 10.0.4
Node: 12.9.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.0.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.1000.4
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.1000.4
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.1000.4
@angular-devkit/core              10.0.4
@angular-devkit/schematics        10.0.4

@schematics/update                0.1000.4
rxjs                              6.5.5
typescript                        3.9.7
webpack                           4.43.0
```

**Anything else relevant?**
This is related to this [issue about the `@ViewChild` decorator](https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/38313).

Issues.Title: No intellisense/autocompletion due to tsconfig files
Issues.Body:
### Affected Package The issue is most probablycaused by package "@angular/cli": "~10.0.4", ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: I can¬¥t say which was the last version this worked on...most probably 9.x.x, but it worked in versions before ;-) ### Description I generated a new Angular Project with Angular CLI 10.0.4. It generated the project and added the different tsconfig files. Unfortunately I could no longer use auto completion. For example I removed this line from app-routing.module.ts `import { Routes, RouterModule } from '@angular/router';` Then I set my cursor to the end of "Routes" in this line and pressed CMD+Space: `const routes: Routes = [];` But it didn¬¥t suggest me to import from @angular/router. This happens as well with Modules which I generated myself. This issue is due to the tsconfig files: tsconfig.json ``` { "files": [], "references": [ { "path": "./tsconfig.app.json" }, { "path": "./tsconfig.spec.json" } ] } ``` tsconfig.app.json ``` { "extends": "./tsconfig.base.json", "compilerOptions": { "outDir": "./out-tsc/app", "types": [], "paths": { "@task/*": ["src/app/task/*"] } }, "files": ["src/main.ts", "src/polyfills.ts"], "include": ["src/**/*.d.ts"] } ``` tsconfig.base.json ``` { "compileOnSave": false, "compilerOptions": { "baseUrl": "./", "outDir": "./dist/out-tsc", "sourceMap": true, "declaration": false, "downlevelIteration": true, "experimentalDecorators": true, "moduleResolution": "node", "importHelpers": true, "target": "es2015", "module": "es2020", "lib": ["es2018", "dom"] } } ``` If I replace my tsconfig.app.json with a tsconfig from another (older) app, it works. e.g. ``` { "compileOnSave": false, "compilerOptions": { "rootDir": ".", "sourceMap": true, "declaration": false, "moduleResolution": "node", "emitDecoratorMetadata": true, "experimentalDecorators": true, "importHelpers": true, "target": "es2015", "module": "esnext", "typeRoots": ["node_modules/@types"], "lib": ["es2017", "dom"], "skipLibCheck": true, "skipDefaultLibCheck": true, "baseUrl": ".", "paths": { "@customer-request/common-ui": ["libs/common-ui/src/index.ts"], "@customer-request/p-house-connection": ["libs/p-house-connection/src/index.ts"], "@customer-request/p-internet-connection": ["libs/p-internet-connection/src/index.ts"], "@customer-request/auth": ["libs/auth/src/index.ts"] } }, "exclude": ["node_modules", "tmp"] } ``` Nevertheless I want to use the new structure but there seems to be any issue in it. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Generate a new App with version 10.0.4 of Angular CLI and try to auto import any Element like shown above. ## üî• Exception or Error No real Error, intellisense/autocomplete just doesn¬¥t work. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler-cli@10.0.6 ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: @angular/compiler-cli@10.0.5 ### Description I think this is related to the feature added in PR https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38226 I had some code like this before: ``` @Output() 'did-finish-load' = new EventEmitter(); ``` (`did-finish-load` is the name of an [Electron API](https://www.electronjs.org/docs/api/web-contents#event-did-finish-load) I was using, I was just trying to keep the same naming scheme). It looks like before, output names like `'did-finish-load'` were just ignored completely. In the newer Angular version, it causes a mysterious build error. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I don't think I can control the compiler-cli version on StackBlitz, so I'll submit a github repo. https://github.com/patdx/reproduction-string-literal-angular Steps: 1. npm install 2. ng build 3. You should get the same error as reported below ## üî• Exception or Error I just tried creating a small test: ``` export class AppComponent { @Output() 'did-finish-load-one' = new EventEmitter(); @Output() didFinishLoadTwo = new EventEmitter(); } ``` With `@angular/compiler-cli@10.0.5`, it produced the following code in dist/main.js: ``` class AppComponent { constructor() { this[ "did-finish-load-one" ] = new _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__["EventEmitter"](); this.didFinishLoadTwo = new _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__[ "EventEmitter" ](); } } AppComponent.…µfac = function AppComponent_Factory(t) { return new (t || AppComponent)(); }; AppComponent.…µcmp = _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__[ "…µ…µdefineComponent" ]({ type: AppComponent, selectors: [["app-root"]], outputs: { didFinishLoadTwo: "didFinishLoadTwo" }, decls: 0, vars: 0, template: function AppComponent_Template(rf, ctx) {}, encapsulation: 2, }); /*@__PURE__*/ (function () { _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__["…µsetClassMetadata"]( AppComponent, [ { type: _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__["Component"], args: [ { selector: "app-root", template: "", }, ], }, ], null, { didFinishLoadTwo: [ { type: _angular_core__WEBPACK_IMPORTED_MODULE_0__["Output"], }, ], } ); })(); ``` This code is running, but "did-finish-load-one" was totally ignored as an output. Oh! Actually, I didn't realize this before. With `@angular/compiler-cli@10.0.6`, I got a build error instead: ```bash # ... chunk {styles} styles.js, styles.js.map (styles) 12.4 kB [initial] [rendered] chunk {vendor} vendor.js, vendor.js.map (vendor) 2.07 MB [initial] [rendered] Date: 2020-07-31T04:45:05.022Z - Hash: ad1181a1bd231bc94cd9 - Time: 5662ms ERROR in ./src/app/app.component.ts 17:19 Module parse failed: Unexpected token (17:19) File was processed with these loaders: * ./node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js You may need an additional loader to handle the result of these loaders. | template: '', | }] > }], null, { did-finish-load-one: [{ | type: Output | }], didFinishLoadTwo: [{ ``` It guess if the compiler supports string literals with decorators like Output, it needs to escape the value here, as in ```diff template: '', }] - }], null, { did-finish-load-one: [{ + }], null, { 'did-finish-load-one': [{ type: Output }], didFinishLoadTwo: [{ ``` ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.0.4
Node: 12.3.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 10.0.7
... animations, common, compiler, core, forms, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes
**Anything else relevant?** As far as I can tell, all that matters is `@angular/compiler-cli@10.0.5` (ignored but no error) vs `@angular/compiler-cli@10.0.6` (build error).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Using an Angular Decorator like @Output with a string literal class member causes a build error" (#38311)

Issues.Title: refactor(language-service): [Ivy[ remove temporary compiler
Issues.Body:
Now that Ivy compiler has a proper `TemplateTypeChecker` interface
(see https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/38105) we no longer need to
keep the temporary compiler implementation.

This commit removes the whole `ivy/compiler` directory and moves two
functions `createTypeCheckingProgramStrategy` and
`getOrCreateTypeCheckScriptInfo` to the `LanguageService` class.

Also re-enable the Ivy LS test since it's no longer blocking development.

Issues.Title: fix(forms): remove validators while cleaning up a control
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, the `cleanUpControl` function (responsible for cleaning up control instance)
was not taking validators into account. As a result, these validators remain registered on a detached
form control instance, thus causing memory leaks. This commit updates the `cleanUpControl` function
logic to also run validators cleanup.

As a part of this change, the logic to setup and cleanup validators was refactored and moved to
separate functions, so that they can be reused in the future.

NOTE: this PR resolves memory leaks in **certain scenarios only**. Other scenarios will be handled in followup PRs.

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): add PURE annotation to getInheritedFactory calls
Issues.Body:
Currently the `getInheritedFactory` function is implemented to allow
closure to remove the call if the base factory is unused.  However, this
method does not work with terser.  By adding the PURE annotation,
terser will also be able to remove the call when unused.

Issues.Title: fix(compiler): Metadata should not include methods on Object.prototype
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes a bug in View Engine whereby the compiler errorneously
thinks that a method of a component has decorator metadata when that
method is one of those in `Object.prototype`, for example `toString`.

This bug is discovered in v10.0.4 of `@angular/language-service` after
the default bundle format was switched from ES5 to ES2015.

ES5 output:
```js
if (propMetadata[propName]) {
    decorators.push.apply(decorators, __spread(propMetadata[propName]));
}
```

ES2015 output:
```js
if (propMetadata[propName]) {
    decorators.push(...propMetadata[propName]);
}
```

The bug was not discovered in ES5 because the polyfill for the spread
operator happily accepts parameters that do not have the `iterable`
symbol:

```js
function __spread() {
    for (var ar = [], i = 0; i < arguments.length; i++)
        ar = ar.concat(__read(arguments[i]));
    return ar;
}
```

whereas in es2015 it‚Äôll fail since the iterable symbol is not present in
`propMetadata['toString']` which evaluates to a function.

Fixes https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/859

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): ensure literal types are retained when `strictNullInputTypes` is disabled
Issues.Body:
Consider the `NgModel` directive which has the `ngModelOptions` input:

```ts
class NgModel {
  @Input() ngModelOptions: { updateOn: 'blur'|'change'|'submit' };
}
```

In a template this may be set using an object literal as follows:

```html
<input ngModel [ngModelOptions]="{updateOn: 'blur'}">
```

This assignment should be accepted, as the object's type aligns with the
`ngModelOptions` input in `NgModel`. However, if the `strictNullInputTypes`
option is disabled this assignment would inadvertently produce an error:

```
Type '{ updateOn: string; }' is not assignable to type '{ updateOn: "blur"|"change"|"submit"; }'.
  Types of property 'updateOn' are incompatible.
    Type 'string' is not assignable to type '"blur"|"change"|"submit"'
```

This is due to the `'blur'` value being inferred to be of type `string`
instead of retaining its literal type. The non-null assertion operator
that is automatically inserted for input binding assignments when
`strictNullInputTypes` is disabled inhibits TypeScript from inferring
the string value as its literal type.

This commit fixes the bug by casting all literal values using an
`as const` cast to avoid widening of the inferred type.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler-cli): ensure literal types are retained when `strictNullInputTypes` is disabled" (#38305)

Issues.Title: feat(dev-infra): save invalid commit message attempts to be restored on next commit attempt
Issues.Body:
When a commit message fails validation, rather than throwing out the commit message entirely
the commit message is saved into a draft file and restored on the next commit attempt.

Issues.Body:
This reverts commit 7f8c2225f2cba3dfcf3ec23e0fe08b7d2e3497e8.

This commit caused test failures internally, which were traced back to the
optimizer removing NgModuleFactory constructor calls when those calls caused
side-effectful registration of NgModules by their ids.

In the below link
[https://angular.io/guide/component-interaction#parent-calls-an-viewchild](https://angular.io/guide/component-interaction#parent-calls-an-viewchild)

I think, the below statement is misguiding the concept

You can't use the local variable technique if an instance of the parent component class must read or write child component values or must call child component methods.

For example

<wisen-child #child></wisen-child>
<button (click)="buttonClicked(child)">Click</button>

In the parent component, using the child local variable as parameter we can read or write child component values or even we can call the child component method.

Issues.Title: Make a way  to add  new DecoratorHandlers or change some existing DecoratorHandlers
Issues.Body:
Angular compiler uses `DecoratorHandlers `  to handle decorators on compile time.

[NgCompiler](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d8c07b83c3d137e3380f98b75685c3513d1fb18c/packages/compiler-cli/src/ngtsc/core/src/compiler.ts) uses them to compile Angular projects.

I want a way to add my custom decorator handles to it or change some default handles behaviour.

I think It would be possible via some method in custom Angular Cli builder.
With this approach, developers can extend Angular compiler.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Make a way  to add  new DecoratorHandlers or change some existing DecoratorHandlers" (#38300)

Issues.Title: i18n guide should have a word about /assets/ folder
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The [i18n guide](https://angular.io/guide/i18n) should explain how does i18n deals with assets (in `/assets/` folder).

In particular, it should address recommendations about how to reference those assets (and how to localize them). I'm currenly facing this issue. My application used to work fine before i18n, but now that extra path component (`/en/` before any resource) spoiled every reference to `/assets` (which now should be `/en/asstes`).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "i18n guide should have a word about /assets/ folder" (#38299)

# üêû bug report ### Affected Package `@angular/compiler-cli` - ngcc ### Description In a medium sized monorepo, containing libraries with secondary entries the `ngcc` seems to fail to properly compile local libraries. The example exception is in the `Exception or Error` section. The triggered command: ``` main-ngcc.js --properties es2015 browser module main --first-only --create-ivy-entry-points --source --tsconfig ./tsconfig.base.json ``` Current workaround: - Trigger `ngcc` before any library is built - Build all the libraries - Trigger `ngcc` on `./dist` instead of `node_modules` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I tried to create small reproduction and didn't succeed. Issues.Title: formatNumber returns irregular whitespace characters for certain locales
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/common


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Not sure


### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> the `formatNumber` method, when used with French locale ('fr') will return strings with the wrong kind of space character as a thousand separator.

A string such as "1 000" will come out of `formatNumber` with a U+202F character instead of U+0020 as whitespace. This causes errors with libraries like jsPDF, where we have to replace the character with a regular space, or else the exported PDF file will be corrupted.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
<!--
Please create and share minimal reproduction of the issue starting with this template: https://stackblitz.com/fork/angular-ivy
-->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-zuba4m


## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**

9.1.1

Issues.Title: refactor(@ngtools/angular): use type guard based narrowing with TS AST
Issues.Body: By leveraging TypeScript's AST type guards, function parameter assumptions and casting can be removed.  Many of these cases caused errors when enabling TypeScript's strict option. This is preliminary work to support enabling full TypeScript strict mode within the project.

Issues.Title: Support an option to build assets for only one locale
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [x] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
The `ng build --prod --localize` build assets in each locale that the application has. An option to build assets only for one locale and reusing them will be a great way to minimize the time of the building of server. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
`"assets": "reuse"` will be a good addition to the locale configuration.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I have tried removing the assets directory from each locale after building but the server can't find them as each locale is loaded separately. I would also like to know other alternatives if any for now.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prefer workspace node_modules
Issues.Body:
In Webpack absolute and relative paths in resolve.module and resolveLoader.modules  behave differently.

A relative path will be scanned similarly to how Node scans for node_modules, by looking through the current directory as well as its ancestors (i.e. ./node_modules, ../node_modules, and on).

With an absolute path, it will only search in the given directory.

With this change we give preference to the workspace level node_nodules directory.

Modules resolved with this change

Issues.Title: Use esbuild for ts/js bundling
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This would be relevant for all packages and projects since it's +100x faster than webpack so the whole community would benefit from this improvement


### Description
Many angular applications grow in the very big codebases and many teams spend days in improving the build, but there is a limitation with the current build tools for angular. Using a faster bundler we could save so much time for all the teams using angular.

**A conservative example of improvement impact**
```
// Developers using angular
X = 5

// Builds per day 
Y = 50     

// Current average build time
Z1 = 5      

// Potential average build time
Z2 = 0.5  

X * Y * Z1 = 1250s/day - (+250000s/year = ~70 hours/year)
X * Y * Z2 = 125s/day - (+25000s/year = ~7 hours/year)

Saved time per year: ~63 hours

This would save a common frontend team 63 hours a year, given they work 200 days a year where many teams work way more.
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
Replace webpack with esbuild


### Describe alternatives you've considered
Using webpack in collaboration with esbuild this could be an option since esbuild don't have the same feature set
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Use esbuild for ts/js bundling" (#18395)

Issues.Title: out of memory on ng serve with i18n and targeting es5
Issues.Body: # üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 9.1.12 ### Description If the Angular project satisfies the following conditions, the memory usage of `ng serve` is excessive * it uses i18n with `@angular/localize` * it is configure to target ES5 * it loads large object from external library. The issue doesn't happen if I changed the target to ES2015 or disabled i18n. `ng build` and `ng serve --no-source-map` is also not affected. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. `ng add @angular/localize` 2. create a translation file and add configuration to `angular.json`. 3. set target in `tsconfig.base.json` to `"es5"` and enable IE11 in browserlist. 4. add external npm library which contains large object and use it from a component. * I can reproduce with `encoding-japanese` and `text-encoding`. 5. run `ng serve` and it consumes a lot of memory. reproduction: https://github.com/nomeaning777/ng-serve-memory-issue-reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error `ng serve` failed with OOM Error. ``` $ ng serve Compiling @angular/core : es2015 as esm2015 Compiling Issues.Title: Angular uses parent node_modules in build process
Issues.Body:
Hello :) # üêû bug report ### Affected Package I'm not sure, but it seems to be the Angular compiler (@angular/cli?) ### Is this a regression? Yes, this bug happens with Angular 10 (10.x or 10.1) but not with Angular 9 ### Description If you run an angular build in a project that `require` `moduleA` from `node_modules`, but you have a parent `../node_modules` that contains `moduleA` then Angular will resolve `moduleA` in `../node_modules` leading to inconsistencies. I think Angular should resolve modules from `./node_modules` first, and if it does not find the module then go in the parent folder. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/Chocobozzz/angular-test This project installs `simple-peer` module in the root folder, and `simple-peer` in `client/` (where the Angular application is). Running `npm run build` in `client/` will fail, but if you remove `../node_modules` the build will succeed. ## üî• Exception or Error In the reproduction project, you'll have issues like (due to the `shims` in `path` of `tsconfig.base.json`): 

ERROR in ../node_modules/readable-stream/lib/_stream_readable.js
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'buffer' in ...
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** Angular 

Angular CLI: 10.0.4
Node: 12.17.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 10.0.6
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: Proposal: detect the absence of the `node_modules` folder while running `ng build` or `ng serve`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command

- [x] build
- [x] serve

### Description
Running `ng build` or `ng serve` in a folder without `node_modules` present results in the following error thrown in terminal:

```
$ ng serve
An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot find module '@angular-devkit/build-angular/package.json'
Require stack:
... stacktrace ...
See "/private/var/folders/7d/r6b3nrdj7bn9t_w_dclm6y9r00kg80/T/ng-PRpMHw/angular-errors.log" for further details.
```

This can happen for example after downloading an example app from angular.io website. Example link:

https://angular.io/generated/zips/form-validation/form-validation.zip

### Describe the solution you'd like
The proposal is to handle the case when `node_modules` folder is not present and output a user-friendly error message that would suggest to run `npm install` or `yarn install`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Proposal: detect the absence of the `node_modules` folder while running `ng build` or `ng serve`" (#18393)

Issues.Title: sass loader prefers node-sass if it exists anywhere in the dep tree
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [x] build
- [x] serve


### Is this a regression?

Probably not.


### Description

Angular CLI prefers node-sass if it exists anywhere in the dependency tree.

This has manifested during an update of `ngx-markdown` from 10.0.0 to 10.1.0 in which one of it's dependency has added node-sass as a `dependency`. The error thrown relates to the SASS implementation not understanding SASS modules.

[The offending line](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/378faa70119a193cff6a4407f70f0229bb88456f/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/styles.ts#L116) in Angular CLI goes against a change that was made in sass-loader v9 to prefer dart-sass. Since the current CLI next version of build-angular (`~0.1001.0-next.2`) updates to sass-loader v9, I feel it would be appropriate to either match its behavior or delegate the choice to sass-loader (by not explicitly providing the `implementation` option`. If that is considered a breaking change, then perhaps an explicit developer choice is made available under `stylePreprocessorOptions` or something similar.


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

Steps and notes in this repo: https://github.com/robjtede/repro-sass-loading

## üî• Exception or Error
```
ERROR in ./src/styles.scss (./node_modules/css-loader/dist/cjs.js??ref--14-1!./node_modules/postcss-loader/src??embedded!./node_modules/resolve-url-loader??ref--14-3!./node_modules/sass-loader/dist/cjs.js??ref--14-4!./src/styles.scss)
Module build failed (from ./node_modules/sass-loader/dist/cjs.js):
SassError: Invalid CSS after "...@include sample": expected "}", was ".yellowBg;"
        on line 4 of src/styles.scss
>>     @include sample.yellowBg;

   -------------^
```


## üåç Your Environment
```
Angular CLI: 10.1.0-next.2
Node: 14.6.0
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.0.5
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.1001.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.1001.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.1001.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.1001.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/core              10.1.0-next.2
@angular-devkit/schematics        10.1.0-next.2
@angular/cli                      10.1.0-next.2
@ngtools/webpack                  10.1.0-next.2
@schematics/angular               10.1.0-next.2
@schematics/update                0.1001.0-next.2
rxjs                              6.5.5
typescript                        3.9.7
webpack                           4.43.0
```

**Anything else relevant?**

Related issues:
- https://github.com/jfcere/ngx-markdown/issues/252
- https://github.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/issues/867
- https://github.com/joypixels/emoji-toolkit/issues/32

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: feat(dialog): Ability to scroll body instead of dialog content
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

It would be nice to have an option to scroll body instead of the dialog content.
If you scroll the body, the browser address bar get automatically hidden on mobile devices and creates a better user experience.

Example from material-ui (scroll=body):
https://material-ui.com/components/dialogs/#scrolling-long-content

Example from bootstrap modal:
https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#scrolling-long-content

#### Use Case
Any dialog with long content
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(dialog): Ability to scroll body instead of dialog content" (#20138)

Issues.Title: fix: add non-null assertions for non-nullable input bindings
Issues.Body:
Due to a bug in the template type checker, binding expressions that include
`undefined` in their type which are bound to directive inputs that don't accept
`undefined` would not be reported as an error, if the directive declares at
least one coercion member using `ngAcceptInputType`. angular/angular#38273
fixes this bug, which uncovers some template issues.

Long-term, it would be best if the directives would be updated to include
`undefined` in an input's type as appropriate. This would require a larger
effort and is likely to introduce some breaking changes to public API.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix: add non-null assertions for non-nullable input bindings" (#20136)

Issues.Title: fix(core): allow for default color and tabindex to be set per instance
Issues.Body:
This is something that came up in #18467. Currently the default values in the `mixinColor` and `mixinTabIndex` are set when the mixin class is created, however we have some components where the default color can be configured through an injection token. These changes add a default field on each instance so that it can be updated after the class is instantiated.

**Note:** marking as a P2, because it's blocking another P2 PR (#18467).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(core): allow for default color and tabindex to be set per instance" (#20125)
